title: John: Acute Left-Sided Bell's Palsy with Facial Motor Deficits
clinical_history: John is a 42-year-old right-handed IT manager who presented acutely to his GP with a sudden onset of facial weakness on the left side, which he noticed on waking up two days ago. He reported an inability to close his left eye fully, drooping of the left corner of his mouth, and difficulty pronouncing certain words. He denies head trauma or recent dental work. Sensory function is largely intact, though he has complained of mild aching near his left ear and reported an altered taste in the left half of his tongue. John reports no vesicular rash or hearing loss. He reports increased tearing from his left eye and food occasionally dribbling from the left half of his mouth when eating.

nprs.affected_area: Left facial muscles (tightness/fatigue, especially end of day; no constant pain, just discomfort)

aggrevating_factors: Attempts at strong facial movements (smiling broadly, closing eyes tightly) increase perceived muscle fatigue and localized ache.
picture: [insert clinical facial anatomy highlighting left facial nerve (CN VII) distribution, particularly orbicularis oculi, orbicularis oris, buccinator, and frontalis muscles, as well as noting facial asymmetry on attempted movements]
easing_factors: Resting facial muscles, artificial tears and using a protective eye patch reduce symptoms of discomfort and irritation.
past_history: Non-contributory; no prior neurological symptoms or facial weakness.
medical_history: Diagnosed with mild hypertension 3 years ago, well-controlled with lifestyle; no diabetes or immunosuppression.
medications: Initiated on oral prednisolone 60 mg daily to be tapered over 7 days, artificial tears for left eye, and advised to use protective eye patch overnight.
personal_history: Lives with spouse and two children. Smoker (10 pack-years, ceased 1 year ago). Moderate alcohol consumption, no recreational drug use. Reports increased stress at work.
imaging: No imaging performed as presentation is classical and no red flag symptoms are present. Would consider MRI brain if symptoms fail to improve or atypical features develop.
